descriptions: A IAO:0000115 SPLIT=|
Bacteria that resist decolorization with acid-alcohol due to waxy cell walls
An organism that thrives in acidic environments, typically below pH 5
Transport that requires energy input
The process by which an organism becomes better suited to its environment
examples: genetic adaptations (mutations, gene acquisitions)|physiological adaptations (enzyme induction, stress responses)

descriptions: Heritable characteristic that increases an organism's fitness by enhancing its ability to survive, reproduce, or respond to environmental challenges.
Surface proteins that enable bacteria to adhere to host tissues
Specialized cellular component that mediates attachment to surfaces, substrates, or other cells through specific molecular interactions.
An organism that requires oxygen for growth
Respiration using oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor
examples: Complete oxidation to CO2 and H2O|High energy yield (up to 38 ATP per glucose)

descriptions: An anaerobe that can survive in the presence of oxygen but does not use it for growth
Cluster of microbial cells that are attached to each other but not to a surface
examples: flocs in wastewater treatment|marine snow|milk clotting by lactic acid bacteria

descriptions: A thick-walled, dormant cell formed by some cyanobacteria
An organism that thrives in alkaline environments, typically above pH 8.5
The process of converting organic nitrogen to ammonia
The breakdown of starch into sugars
An organism that grows in the absence of oxygen
Respiration using alternative terminal electron acceptors instead of oxygen
Photosynthesis that does not produce oxygen
The synthesis of compounds that inhibit the growth of other microorganisms
The ability of bacteria to survive exposure to antibiotics
examples: aminoglycoside resistance|beta-lactam resistance|fluoroquinolone resistance|macrolide resistance|tetracycline resistance

descriptions: The ability of microorganisms to survive exposure to antimicrobial compounds
Protruding structures on bacterial cells
A type of spore formed by the fragmentation of fungal hyphae
Sexual spores produced in an ascus, typically by ascomycete fungi
An organism that synthesizes organic compounds from inorganic carbon sources
Metabolic pathway through which organisms synthesize organic compounds from inorganic substances using light or chemical energy.
An organism unable to synthesize a particular organic compound required for growth
Internal flagella-like structures in spirochetes
examples: endoflagella in Borrelia|periplasmic flagella in Treponema

descriptions: A rod-shaped bacterial cell
An organism that thrives under high pressure conditions
An organism that can survive under high pressure but does not require it for optimal growth
examples: Various marine bacteria that can survive in both shallow and deep waters

descriptions: Sexual spores produced on a basidium, typically by basidiomycete fungi
Asexual reproduction where a cell divides into two identical daughter cells
examples: Most bacteria reproduce by binary fission

descriptions: A structured community of microorganisms enclosed in a self-produced matrix
Constituent element of a microbial community encased in a self-produced matrix of extracellular polymeric substances attached to a surface.
The process of creating structured microbial communities attached to surfaces
The movement and transformation of elements through biological and geological processes
The production of light by living organisms
Asexual reproduction where a new cell grows from the surface of the parent cell
Specialized cellular component that enables an organism to control its vertical position in a liquid environment through regulation of density or displacement.
An organism that requires or grows better in the presence of elevated levels of carbon dioxide
A layer of polysaccharides or proteins surrounding the cell
examples: K antigen in E. coli|pneumococcal capsule

descriptions: The conversion of inorganic carbon (usually CO₂) into organic compounds
The source from which an organism obtains carbon for building cellular materials
An organism that can use carbon monoxide as its sole source of energy and carbon
The pattern in which bacterial cells are organized relative to each other
examples: diplococci (pairs)|palisades (side-by-side)|sarcinae (cuboidal packets of eight)|staphylococci (grape-like clusters)|streptococci (chains)|tetrads (groups of four)

descriptions: Complex of layers that surrounds a cell, providing structural support, protection, and mediating interactions with the external environment.
A classification of microbial cells based on their longitudinal dimension ranges
examples: low length (1.3-2 μm)|mid length (2-3 μ|very low length (<1.3 μm)

descriptions: The physical form or appearance of a microbial cell
The physical dimensions of a microbial cell
examples: diameter (for spherical cells)|length (typically 0.5-5 μm for most bacteria)|width (typically 0.2-2 μm for most bacteria)

descriptions: Distinctive physical, chemical, or structural property of the rigid layer surrounding certain cells that determines its functional attributes and taxonomic classification.
Molecular constituent of the rigid structure surrounding certain cells that contributes to its structural integrity, function, or specificity.
A classification of microbial cells based on their lateral dimension ranges
examples: high width (>0.9 μm)|low width (0.5-0.65 μm)|mid width (0.65-0.9 μm)|very low width (<0.5 μm)

descriptions: Distinctive property of a cell that contributes to its identity, function, or classification within biological systems.
Distinct structural or functional part of a cell that contributes to its organization, metabolism, or other cellular activities.
Coordinated series of molecular events occurring within or involving a cell that serves a specific biological function or outcome.
Substance synthesized, modified, or secreted by a cell as a result of its metabolic activities or in response to environmental stimuli.
The breakdown of cellulose into glucose
Distinguishing quality, property, or feature of a biological entity that contributes to its identity, function, or classification.
An organism that obtains energy from inorganic chemical reactions and carbon from CO2
An organism that obtains both energy and carbon from organic compounds
examples: E. coli, Bacillus, Pseudomonas|Most bacteria and fungi

descriptions: Movement of an organism in response to chemical stimuli
A thick-walled resting spore formed from a cell of a fungal hypha
The taxonomic rank below phylum and above order
Significance of a microorganism, biological process, or trait in relation to human or animal health, disease diagnosis, treatment, or prevention.
A spherical bacterial cell
Proteins produced in response to cold stress that maintain RNA translation and membrane fluidity
examples: CspA family proteins|RNA helicases|fatty acid desaturases

descriptions: Cellular reaction to sudden temperature decrease
examples: membrane fluidity adjustments|production of cold shock proteins

descriptions: The establishment of a microbial population in a host or environment
The height profile of a bacterial colony
The edge characteristics of a bacterial colony
The appearance and characteristics of a bacterial colony grown on solid media
examples: size, shape, color, texture, margin, elevation

descriptions: The surface characteristics of a bacterial colony
A symbiotic relationship where one organism benefits and the other is unaffected
examples: normal skin flora|some components of gut microbiota

descriptions: Coordinated action or response exhibited by a population of microorganisms that emerges from individual activities and interactions within the group.
Spatial, temporal, or functional organization formed by multiple microbial species interacting within a defined environment.
Organic compounds that help organisms maintain osmotic balance without interfering with cellular processes
The ability of a cell to take up extracellular DNA
examples: Induced competence in laboratory conditions|Natural competence in Bacillus subtilis

descriptions: Constituent part or element of a biological system that contributes to its structure, function, or organization.
Asexual spores produced by fungi, typically at the tips of specialized hyphae
The transfer of genetic material between bacterial cells through direct contact
examples: F plasmid transfer in E. coli|R plasmid transfer

descriptions: Bacterial adaptive immune system providing resistance against foreign genetic elements
exact_synonyms: CRISPR|Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats
full_name synonym: Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats

descriptions: The ability of a microorganism to be grown in laboratory conditions
examples: culturable (can be grown in laboratory media)|unculturable (cannot be grown with current techniques)|viable but non-culturable (VBNC) state

descriptions: A thick-walled, dormant cell formed by some bacteria
Period where death rate exceeds growth rate, resulting in population decline
examples: extreme nutrient depletion|programmed cell death|toxic waste accumulation

descriptions: The reduction of nitrate to nitrogen gas
Biological mechanism through which an organism or cell undergoes progressive changes in structure, function, or complexity over time.
Biological catalysts grouped according to the type of chemical reaction they facilitate, their substrate specificity, or their molecular structure.
Distinctive biological trait or property that enables the identification, classification, or differentiation of organisms, structures, or processes.
An organism capable of nitrogen fixation
The process by which cells become specialized for specific functions
examples: aerial mycelium formation in Streptomyces|endospore formation in Bacillus|heterocyst formation in cyanobacteria

descriptions: The existence of two distinct morphological forms in the same organism
examples: prosthecate-budding cell cycle in Caulobacter|rod-coccoid transitions|yeast-hyphal dimorphism in Candida

descriptions: A flat, circular-shaped cell
The highest taxonomic rank in biological classification
A temporary period of minimal metabolic activity
Specialized cellular form that enables an organism to survive unfavorable environmental conditions in a state of reduced metabolic activity.
A cell shaped like two spheres connected by a narrow bridge
The role and position a species has in its environment
Series of interactions or changes involving organisms and their environment that affects community structure, resource distribution, or ecosystem function.
Heritable characteristic that influences how an organism interacts with other species, utilizes resources, or adapts to environmental conditions.
Symbiotic relationship where one organism lives on the external surface of another
examples: dental microbiota|epidermal bacteria on mammals|gut microbiota

descriptions: A compound that receives electrons in energy-generating reactions
A compound that provides electrons for energy-generating reactions
A highly resistant, dormant structure formed within certain bacteria
Symbiotic relationship where one organism lives within the cells or body of another
examples: Buchnera in aphids|Rhizobium in plant root nodules|Wolbachia in insect cells

descriptions: Series of biochemical reactions through which organisms acquire, transform, store, or utilize energy for cellular functions and maintenance.
The biological catalysis carried out by specific proteins
Heritable change in gene expression or cellular phenotype that occurs without alterations to the underlying DNA sequence.
Mechanism or phenomenon that contributes to genetic change over time, resulting in adaptation, speciation, or other alterations in the heritable characteristics of populations.
A spore formed outside the mother cell
Period of growth where cells divide at a constant rate
examples: balanced growth|constant doubling time|maximum growth rate

descriptions: Existing or occurring outside of cells
Complex carbohydrates secreted by microorganisms
An organism that requires very high salt concentrations, typically above 15-20% NaCl
An organism that thrives in physically or geochemically extreme conditions
examples: acidophiles (low pH)|alkaliphiles (high pH)|halophiles (high salt)|psychrophiles (low temperature)|thermophiles (high temperature)

descriptions: Describing an optional capability or adaptation that is not essential
An organism that can grow both in the presence and absence of oxygen
The taxonomic rank below order and above genus
Requiring specific or complex nutritional requirements for growth
examples: Bifidobacterium (requires specific carbohydrates)|Haemophilus (requires X and V factors)|Lactobacillus (requires specific amino acids)

descriptions: Energy-yielding process where organic compounds serve as both electron donors and acceptors
examples: alcoholic fermentation|lactic acid fermentation|mixed acid fermentation

descriptions: Growing in long, thread-like structures
Short, hair-like appendages on bacterial cells, often involved in adhesion
examples: P fimbriae in uropathogenic E. coli|Type 1 fimbriae in E. coli

descriptions: A whip-like appendage that enables cell movement
examples: amphitrichous (flagella at both ends)|lophotrichous (multiple flagella at one end)|monotrichous (single polar flagellum)|peritrichous (flagella all over the cell)

descriptions: A cell shaped like a laboratory flask, with a swollen base and narrower neck
Reproductive unit of fungi that contains genetic material and enables dispersal, reproduction, or survival under adverse conditions.
Gas-filled structures that provide buoyancy in aquatic environments
The percentage of guanine and cytosine nucleotides in DNA
examples: {'high GC content (>60%)': 'Streptomyces, Mycobacterium'}|{'low GC content (<30%)': 'Clostridium, some Mycoplasma'}

descriptions: A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage above 66.3% in an organism's DNA
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage below 42.65% in an organism's DNA
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage between 42.65% and 57% in an organism's DNA
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage between 57% and 66.3% in an organism's DNA
The time required for a population to double in size
examples: {'fast growth': '< 20 minutes (E. coli in optimal conditions)'}|{'moderate growth': '1-3 hours (many soil bacteria)'}|{'slow growth': '> 24 hours (Mycobacterium tuberculosis)'}

descriptions: Discrete unit of heritable information that can be maintained, replicated, and potentially transferred between organisms.
Process through which genetic material is transferred between organisms or cells, leading to recombination, acquisition of new traits, or genetic diversity.
Biological mechanism involving the replication, expression, modification, or transmission of genetic material within or between organisms.
The total amount of DNA in an organism's genome
examples: {'large genomes (>6 Mbp)': 'Streptomyces coelicolor (8.7 Mbp)'}|{'medium genomes (1.5-6 Mbp)': 'E. coli (4.6 Mbp)'}|{'small genomes (<1.5 Mbp)': 'Mycoplasma genitalium (0.58 Mbp)'}

descriptions: Discrete region or component of an organism's genome that serves a specific function in genetic regulation, expression, or organization.
Large regions of horizontal gene transfer in bacterial genomes
Heritable characteristic determined by the structure, content, or organization of an organism's genetic material.
The taxonomic rank below family and above species
Movement across surfaces without the use of flagella
Regulatory protein that controls the expression of many genes across various pathways
examples: CRP (catabolite repression)|Fur (ferric uptake regulator)|Lrp (leucine-responsive protein)|RpoS (sigma factor)

descriptions: Bacteria that do not retain crystal violet stain due to thin peptidoglycan layer and appear red/pink when counterstained with safranin
exact_synonyms: Gram-negative bacterium|Gram-stain negative bacterium|Gram reaction negative|Gram(−)|gram-negative

descriptions: Bacteria that retain crystal violet stain due to thick peptidoglycan layer and appear purple after Gram staining
exact_synonyms: Gram-positive bacterium|Gram-stain positive bacterium|Gram reaction positive|Gram(+)|gram-positive

descriptions: A differential staining technique that distinguishes bacteria based on cell wall composition
Distinctive property related to how an organism increases in size, number, or complexity under specific environmental conditions.
Environmental or physiological factors that limit or define the parameters under which an organism can survive, reproduce, or flourish.
Characteristic mode of cellular proliferation, colony formation, or population increase exhibited by an organism under specific conditions.
The speed at which microbial population increases
examples: generation time|doubling time|exponential growth rate|specific growth rate

descriptions: The natural environment in which an organism lives
An organism that thrives in high salinity environments
An organism that can grow in the presence of high salt concentrations but does not require them
Proteins produced in response to heat stress that protect cellular proteins from denaturation
Cellular reaction to sudden temperature increase
examples: chaperone activity upregulation|production of heat shock proteins

descriptions: The breakdown of red blood cells
examples: alpha-hemolysis (partial hemolysis, greenish)|beta-hemolysis (complete hemolysis, clear)|gamma-hemolysis (no hemolysis)

descriptions: Specialized cells in some cyanobacteria that fix nitrogen
An organism that obtains carbon from organic compounds
Adhesive structure at the end of a stalk or on a cell body
The movement of genetic material between organisms other than by vertical transmission
An enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of a chemical bond
examples: amylases (starch hydrolysis)|lipases (lipid hydrolysis)|nucleases (nucleic acid hydrolysis)|proteases (protein hydrolysis)

descriptions: An organism that thrives at extremely high temperatures, typically above 80°C
Intracellular structures for storing nutrients or other compounds
examples: gas vesicles|glycogen granules|polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) granules|polyphosphate granules|sulfur granules

descriptions: The invasion and multiplication of microorganisms in host tissues
Relationship between biological entities involving physical contact, chemical exchange, or signal transmission that affects their behavior or properties.
Relationship between a bacterium and a virus that infects it, involving molecular recognition, genetic exchange, defense, or lytic processes.
Relationship between an organism and its surroundings that involves sensing, responding to, or modifying physical, chemical, or biological factors.
Relationship between a microorganism and the organism in which it lives, involving molecular, cellular, or physiological exchanges that affect both parties.
Relationship or exchange between different microbial species or populations that affects their behavior, metabolism, or survival within a shared environment.
Existing or occurring within a cell
examples: facultative intracellular bacteria (Listeria, Salmonella)|obligate intracellular bacteria (Rickettsia, Chlamydia)

descriptions: Penetration of host cells or tissues
Property or behavior of an organism observed under controlled experimental conditions that aids in its identification, classification, or research application.
Initial period of growth where cells adapt to new environment before dividing
examples: adaptation to new nutrients|repair of cellular damage|synthesis of new enzymes

descriptions: The series of changes an organism undergoes during its existence
Distinct stage in the development or reproduction of an organism characterized by specific morphological, physiological, or behavioral attributes.
The breakdown of lipids into fatty acids and glycerol
A major component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria
Process by which a molecule, structure, or organism is directed to or maintained in a specific spatial position within a cell, tissue, or environment.
The integration of bacteriophage DNA into the bacterial chromosome
Characteristic feature of an organism or population that is visible to the naked eye and contributes to its identification, ecological role, or evolutionary history.
Movement, orientation and navigation along magnetic field lines
An organism that grows best at moderate temperatures, typically between 20°C and 45°C
Heritable characteristic that determines an organism's capacity to perform specific biochemical transformations or utilize particular substrates.
The biological production of methane as a metabolic byproduct
examples: CO2 reduction with H2|acetate fermentation to methane|methanol reduction to methane

descriptions: The addition of methyl groups to DNA or proteins
An organism that requires oxygen for growth but at concentrations lower than atmospheric levels
DNA sequences that can move within or between genomes
An organism that grows optimally in 5-15% NaCl
Heritable characteristic related to the physical form, structure, or appearance of an organism or its components.
Biological mechanism through which an organism achieves directed or random movement in its environment through structural adaptations or behavioral responses.
Specialized cellular component that enables an organism to move actively within its environment through mechanical, chemical, or other means.
A symbiotic relationship where both organisms benefit
examples: gut microbiota providing vitamins to host|nitrogen-fixing bacteria in root nodules

descriptions: Long-chain fatty acids found in the cell walls of Mycobacteria and related genera
The formation of symbiotic associations between fungi and plant roots
An organism that grows best at neutral pH, typically between pH 6.5 and 7.5
The biological oxidation of ammonia to nitrite and then to nitrate
The process of converting atmospheric nitrogen (N2) into ammonia
examples: Azotobacter in soil|Rhizobium in legume root nodules

descriptions: The process of forming root nodules in leguminous plants for nitrogen fixation
examples: Nod factor signaling|Rhizobium-legume symbiosis|root nodule formation

descriptions: The region in a prokaryotic cell that contains the genetic material
Process by which an organism acquires, transforms, and incorporates external substances into its metabolism for growth, energy production, or other cellular functions.
Describing a requirement that is essential and cannot be substituted
An organism that absolutely requires oxygen for growth and cannot grow in its absence
An organism that cannot tolerate oxygen and grows only in its complete absence
A thick-walled sexual spore produced by oomycetes
The taxonomic rank below class and above family
Classification of living beings based on the specific environmental parameters required for their optimal development and reproduction.
Classification of living beings based on their specific needs for essential nutrients, compounds, or growth factors.

labels: microbe characterized by relation to oxygen
descriptions: Classification of living beings based on their requirement for, tolerance of, or utilization of molecular oxygen in their metabolism.

labels: microbe characterized by relation to ph
descriptions: Classification of living beings based on their optimal acidity or alkalinity range for growth, survival, or metabolic activity.

labels: microbe characterized by relation to pressure
descriptions: Classification of living beings based on their tolerance for and adaptation to specific hydrostatic or atmospheric pressure conditions.

labels: microbe characterized by relation to salt concentration
descriptions: Classification of living beings based on their tolerance for and adaptation to specific ranges of environmental salinity.

labels: microbe characterized by relation to temperature
descriptions: Classification of living beings based on their optimal thermal range for growth, survival, or metabolic activity.
Classification of living beings based on their characteristic external morphology, cellular geometry, or structural configuration.
Classification of living beings based on their mode of nutrition and energy acquisition from the environment.
An organism that can grow in environments with high sugar concentrations
Regulation of solute concentration within cells in response to environmental osmolarity
examples: compatible solute accumulation|ion transport|water channel regulation

descriptions: Cellular reaction to reactive oxygen species
examples: production of catalase|production of peroxidases|production of superoxide dismutase

descriptions: An enzyme that catalyzes the transfer of electrons from one molecule to another
The relationship between an organism and molecular oxygen for growth
Photosynthesis that produces oxygen as a byproduct
A symbiotic relationship where one organism benefits at the expense of the other
Transport that does not require energy input
The ability of an organism to cause disease
examples: evasion of host immune responses|invasion of host tissues|production of toxins

descriptions: A genomic island containing genes associated with virulence
examples: LEE in pathogenic E. coli|SPI-1 in Salmonella

descriptions: A polymer that forms the cell wall of most bacteria
examples: thick in Gram-positive bacteria|thin in Gram-negative bacteria

descriptions: A measure of the breadth of hydrogen ion concentrations that a microorganism can tolerate, calculated as the difference between the maximum and minimum viable pH values
examples: {'narrow range (<1 pH unit)': 'specialist organisms'}|{'wide range (>5 pH units)': 'generalist organisms'}

descriptions: The specific pH at which an organism exhibits maximum growth rate
examples: pH 10.0 for Bacillus alcalophilus|pH 3.0 for Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans|pH 7.0 for E. coli

descriptions: The pH range or specific pH at which an organism grows optimally
The span of pH values within which an organism can grow
examples: pH 1-5 for acidophiles|pH 6.5-7.5 for neutrophiles|pH 8.5-11 for alkaliphiles

descriptions: The ability of an organism to survive exposure to pH values outside its optimal growth range
Biological mechanism employed by bacteria and archaea to protect themselves against viral infection and genetic invasion by bacteriophages.
An organism that obtains energy from light and carbon from CO2
An organism that obtains energy from light but carbon from organic compounds
The process of converting light energy into chemical energy
examples: anoxygenic photosynthesis (purple and green bacteria)|oxygenic photosynthesis (cyanobacteria)

descriptions: Movement in response to light stimulus
examples: negative phototaxis (movement away from light)|positive phototaxis (movement toward light)

descriptions: The taxonomic rank below domain and above class
Coordinated series of biological activities that maintains homeostasis, responds to stimuli, or contributes to the integrated functioning of an organism.
Temporary condition of an organism characterized by specific patterns of metabolic activity, gene expression, or cellular function in response to internal or external factors.
Heritable characteristic that affects how an organism's biological systems function, respond to stimuli, or maintain homeostasis.
An organism that thrives under high pressure conditions (synonym of barophile)
Colored compounds produced by microorganisms
The production of colored compounds by microorganisms
Hair-like appendages on bacterial cells, often involved in motility or DNA transfer
The ability of microorganisms to enhance plant growth
examples: biocontrol of pathogens|induced systemic resistance|phosphate solubilization|phytohormone production

descriptions: A small, circular, extrachromosomal DNA molecule
examples: F plasmids (fertility/conjugation)|R plasmids (antibiotic resistance)|Ti plasmids (plant tumor induction)

descriptions: The ability of bacteria to change shape or size in response to environmental conditions
examples: Corynebacterium (club-shaped and irregular)|L-form transition|Mycoplasma (lack cell wall)|cell wall deficient forms|filamentous growth under stress

descriptions: Systematic series of actions, changes, or functions that occur in organisms over time and lead to a specific outcome or state.
Bacteriophage DNA integrated into a bacterial genome
Thin extensions of the cell and cell wall
examples: Caulobacter crescentus stalk|Hyphomicrobium appendages|Hyphomonas neptunium stalk

descriptions: Cellular process through which amino acids are assembled into polypeptide chains according to genetic instructions encoded in DNA and mediated by RNA.
The breakdown of proteins into smaller polypeptides or amino acids
examples: extracellular proteases for nutrient acquisition|intracellular proteases for protein turnover

descriptions: An organism able to synthesize all its organic compounds from inorganic carbon sources
examples: environmentally isolated strains|wild-type strains of most bacteria

descriptions: An organism that thrives at relatively low temperatures, typically below 15°C
Term or concept that modifies, specifies, or contextualizes another entity, property, or relationship within an ontological framework.
Cell-to-cell communication mechanism that allows bacteria to detect population density
examples: AHL signaling in Gram-negative bacteria|AI-2 interspecies signaling|peptide signaling in Gram-positive bacteria

descriptions: Control of gene expression or protein activity
Biological process that controls the rate, timing, or extent of other processes through modulation of molecular activities or cellular responses.
Biological mechanism through which organisms produce offspring, transfer genetic material, or increase their population.
Specialized cellular component or assembly that functions in the production, development, or dispersal of offspring.
The specific molecular or cellular processes that confer antimicrobial resistance
examples: active efflux|bypass mechanisms|enzymatic inactivation|reduced permeability|target modification

descriptions: Energy-yielding process using an electron transport chain with external electron acceptors
examples: aerobic respiration (oxygen as terminal electron acceptor)|anaerobic respiration (other terminal electron acceptors)

descriptions: System protecting bacteria from foreign DNA by cleaving unmethylated recognition sites
examples: Type I R-M systems|Type II R-M systems|Type III R-M systems

descriptions: The cellular structure where protein synthesis occurs
Crystalline surface layer protein or glycoprotein coating the outside of many bacteria
A measure of the breadth of sodium chloride concentrations that a microorganism can tolerate, calculated as the difference between the maximum and minimum viable salinity values
examples: {'narrow range (<1% NaCl)': 'stenohaline organisms'}|{'wide range (>8% NaCl)': 'euryhaline organisms'}

descriptions: The salinity range or specific salinity at which an organism grows optimally
Compounds not directly involved in normal growth but often having ecological functions
The process of moving molecules from inside a cell to the external environment
Specialized molecular machinery for protein secretion across membranes
examples: Type I secretion system|Type II secretion system|Type III secretion system (injectisome)|Type IV secretion system|Type V secretion system|Type VI secretion system

descriptions: Having an outer tube-like structure enclosing filaments of cells
Compounds that bind and transport iron into cells
Protein subunit of RNA polymerase required for initiation of transcription
Process by which cells detect and respond to external or internal stimuli through cascades of molecular interactions that regulate cellular functions.
A loosely attached layer of extracellular polymeric substances
Differentiated cellular form that has developed specific structural or functional adaptations to perform particular biological roles.
The basic unit of biological classification
A spiral-shaped bacterial cell
A spiral-shaped bacterium with axial filaments
Asexual spores produced within a sporangium
The process of forming spores
examples: endospore formation in Bacillus|exospore formation in Streptomyces

descriptions: A cell with four approximately equal sides and right angles
Non-reproductive appendage extending from a bacterial cell
A cell with multiple pointed projections extending from a central body
Period where growth rate equals death rate, resulting in constant population
examples: nutrient limitation|quorum sensing activation|waste product accumulation

descriptions: Cellular component that serves to accumulate, maintain, and make available specific molecules, compounds, or energy reserves for metabolic use.
A genetic variant or subtype of a microorganism
examples: Bacillus subtilis 168|Escherichia coli K-12|Streptomyces coelicolor A3(2)

descriptions: Cellular reactions to environmental challenges
examples: cold shock response|heat shock response|oxidative stress response|osmotic stress response

descriptions: Physical component or arrangement of components in an organism that has a specific form, organization, and function.
An organism that uses sulfate as an electron acceptor in anaerobic respiration
Coordinated movement of bacterial populations across surfaces
examples: Bacillus subtilis swarming|Proteus mirabilis swarming|Pseudomonas aeruginosa swarming

descriptions: A close and long-term biological interaction between different biological organisms
examples: commensalism (one benefits, other unaffected)|mutualism (both benefit)|parasitism (one benefits, other harmed)

descriptions: Biological mechanism through which different species establish and maintain long-term ecological relationships that may be mutualistic, commensal, or parasitic.
Metabolic cooperation between different microbial species
Unique designation assigned to a biological taxon that enables its precise reference, distinction, and retrieval in classification systems.
Hierarchical level in the biological classification system that indicates the relative position and inclusivity of a taxonomic group.
A polymer in the cell wall of Gram-positive bacteria
examples: lipoteichoic acids (attached to membrane)|wall teichoic acids (attached to peptidoglycan)

descriptions: A measure of the breadth of thermal conditions that a microorganism can withstand, calculated as the difference between the maximum and minimum viable temperature values
The specific temperature at which an organism exhibits maximum growth rate
examples: 100°C for Pyrolobus fumarii|37°C for E. coli|70°C for Thermus aquaticus

descriptions: The temperature range or specific temperature at which an organism grows optimally
The span of temperatures within which an organism can grow
examples: 0-15°C for psychrophiles|20-45°C for mesophiles|45-80°C for thermophiles

descriptions: The ability of an organism to survive exposure to temperatures outside its optimal growth range
An organism that thrives at relatively high temperatures, typically above 45°C
A poisonous substance produced by an organism
examples: endotoxins (part of cell structure)|enterotoxins (affecting intestines)|exotoxins (secreted)|neurotoxins (affecting nervous system)

descriptions: Protein that binds to specific DNA sequences to control the transcription of genetic information from DNA to RNA.
The transfer of bacterial DNA from one bacterium to another via a bacteriophage
examples: Generalized transduction (random bacterial DNA)|Specialized transduction (specific bacterial DNA)

descriptions: An enzyme that catalyzes the transfer of a functional group from one molecule to another
examples: aminotransferases (transfer amino groups)|kinases (transfer phosphate groups)|methyltransferases (transfer methyl groups)

descriptions: The uptake and incorporation of exogenous DNA from the environment
examples: Artificial transformation in laboratory conditions|Natural competence in Streptococcus pneumoniae

descriptions: Mechanisms for moving molecules across cellular membranes
A DNA sequence that can change its position within a genome
A cell with a three-sided shape
A chain of cells in filamentous bacteria, especially cyanobacteria
Movement mediated by extension and retraction of type IV pili
Signal transduction system consisting of a sensor histidine kinase and a response regulator
A state in which cells are alive but cannot be cultured on standard media
examples: Escherichia coli under stress|Vibrio cholerae in aquatic environments

descriptions: A curved rod-shaped bacterial cell
The degree or severity of pathogenicity
Molecule, structure, or mechanism produced by a pathogen that enables it to establish infection, evade host defenses, or cause damage to host tissues.
Biological mechanism through which a pathogen causes disease by invading, damaging, or disrupting host tissues or functions.
The breakdown of xylan (hemicellulose) into xylose
Motile spores with flagella, typically produced by algae and some fungi
A thick-walled resting spore resulting from the fusion of two compatible hyphae
A physical force exerted per unit area in an environment that influences microbial cellular processes, protein structure, and membrane fluidity.
The specific temperature at which a microorganism exhibits maximum metabolic activity and growth rate within its viable range.
The span of temperatures within which a microorganism can maintain metabolic functions and population viability.
The specific hydrogen ion concentration at which a microorganism achieves its maximum growth rate and metabolic efficiency.
The span of hydrogen ion concentrations within which a microorganism can maintain cellular homeostasis and sustain growth.
The specific concentration of sodium chloride at which a microorganism exhibits maximum growth rate and metabolic efficiency.
The span of sodium chloride concentrations within which a microorganism can maintain osmotic balance and cellular functions.
A measure of the breadth of sodium chloride concentrations that a microorganism can tolerate, calculated as the difference between the maximum and minimum viable salinity values.
A microorganism that can grow at temperatures near 0°C but has optimal growth at higher temperatures.
A microorganism that can grow at temperatures near 50°C but has optimal growth at lower temperatures.
A microorganism that grows optimally at temperatures between 60°C and 80°C.
A microorganism that grows optimally at temperatures above 90°C.
A microorganism that does not require salt for optimal growth and survival.
A microorganism that grows optimally in environments with low salt concentrations, typically between 2-5% NaCl.

A microorganism that grows optimally in environments with both high salt concentrations (typically 2-5% NaCl, but can tolerate up to 25% NaCl) and high pH (typically 9-11, but can grow at pH values up to 12).
A microorganism that grows optimally at very low pH values, typically between pH 1 and 3.
A microorganism that can grow in acidic conditions below pH 5 but does not require them for optimal growth.
A microorganism that can grow in alkaline conditions above pH 9 but does not require them for optimal growth.
A microorganism that grows optimally at very high pH values, typically above pH 10.
A microorganism that can grow in acidic conditions but does not require them for optimal growth.
A microorganism that requires acidic conditions for growth and survival.
A microorganism that primarily uses oxygen for respiration but can also grow without it using alternative metabolic pathways.
A microorganism that requires oxygen for growth but at concentrations lower than those found in air (typically 2-10% oxygen).
A microorganism that can tolerate low levels of oxygen but does not require such conditions for growth.
An anaerobic microorganism that does not use oxygen for metabolism but is not inhibited by its presence.
A microorganism that absolutely requires oxygen for growth and cannot grow under anaerobic conditions.
A microorganism for which oxygen is toxic and inhibits growth, requiring strictly anaerobic conditions.
An organism that uses light energy for photosynthesis, producing oxygen as a byproduct.
An organism that uses light energy for photosynthesis without producing oxygen.
An organism that uses energy from chemical reactions to fix carbon dioxide for growth.
An organism that obtains both energy and carbon from organic compounds.
An organism that obtains energy from the oxidation of inorganic compounds.
An organism that obtains energy from the oxidation of organic compounds.
An organism that uses light as its primary energy source.
An organism that obtains energy from chemical reactions.
An organism adapted to environments with low nutrient levels.
An organism adapted to environments with high nutrient levels.
An organism that uses inorganic compounds for both energy and carbon.
An organism capable of both autotrophic and heterotrophic nutrition.
An organism that uses inorganic compounds for energy but organic compounds for carbon.
An organism that uses organic compounds for both energy and carbon.
An organism that uses inorganic compounds for energy and CO2 for carbon.
An organism that can use one-carbon compounds as a source of energy and carbon.
An organism that uses methane as its sole source of carbon and energy.
An organism that obtains energy from the oxidation of molecular hydrogen.
An organism that oxidizes hydrogen for energy.
An organism that produces hydrogen as a byproduct of its metabolism.
An organism capable of converting atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia.
An organism that produces methane as a byproduct of its metabolism.
An organism that oxidizes sulfur compounds for energy.
An organism that reduces nitrate to nitrogen gas in anaerobic respiration.
A microorganism capable of self-propelled movement.
A microorganism incapable of self-propelled movement.
A motile microorganism that moves using one or more flagella.
A flagellated microorganism with flagella distributed over the entire cell surface.
A flagellated microorganism with a tuft of flagella at one or both poles of the cell.
A flagellated microorganism with a single flagellum at one pole of the cell.
A motile microorganism that moves using numerous short, hair-like structures called cilia.
A motile microorganism that moves by sliding over surfaces without the use of flagella or cilia.
A motile microorganism that moves using type IV pili in a jerky, start-stop motion.
A motile microorganism that moves passively over surfaces due to the production of extracellular substances.
A resting spore produced by myxobacteria during unfavorable conditions.
Asexual spores produced by fungi, typically at the tips of specialized hyphae.
A thick-walled resting spore formed from a cell of a fungal hypha.
A protective cyst-like structure containing sporozoites in some protists.
A dormant stage of some dinoflagellates, formed under unfavorable conditions.
Small, multicellular propagules produced by some bryophytes for asexual reproduction.
A spore formed without fusion of gametes, typically in zygomycetes.
Asexual spores formed by the disarticulation of vegetative hyphae.
Asexual spores produced on a stalk-like structure called a sterigma.
A compact mass of hardened fungal mycelium containing food reserves.
A type of resting spore produced by rust and smut fungi.
Asexual spores produced by rust fungi during their life cycle.
Asexual spores produced within a pycnidium, a flask-shaped fruiting body.
Asexual spores produced in chains at the tips of conidiophores.
Non-motile spores that lack flagella, typically produced by algae.
Non-motile spores that lack the ability to swim.
An organism that can tolerate high pressure but grows optimally at normal atmospheric pressure.
An organism that is adversely affected by high pressure conditions.
An organism that requires high pressure for growth and cannot grow at atmospheric pressure.
An organism that grows optimally under high pressure but can also grow at atmospheric pressure.
An organism adapted to extremely high pressure environments.
An organism adapted to low pressure environments.
An organism adapted to grow at standard atmospheric pressure.
An organism that grows optimally at moderately high pressures.
An organism that grows optimally at very high pressures.
An organism that can only grow within a narrow range of pressures.
An organism that can grow across a wide range of pressures.
An organism whose growth or metabolism is negatively affected by changes in pressure.
An organism that can withstand significant changes in pressure without adverse effects.
An organism that has evolved to thrive under specific pressure conditions.
An organism that grows optimally under both high pressure and acidic conditions.
An organism that grows optimally under both high pressure and alkaline conditions.
An organism that grows optimally under both high pressure and high salinity conditions.
An organism that grows optimally under both high pressure and low temperature conditions.
An organism that grows optimally under both high pressure and high temperature conditions.
An organism that uses inorganic compounds for energy and carbon under high pressure conditions.
An organism that uses organic compounds for energy and carbon under high pressure conditions.
An organism adapted to low-nutrient environments under high pressure conditions.
An organism that lives within rock or mineral substrates under high pressure conditions.
An organism that can tolerate a range of pressure conditions but does not necessarily require high pressure for optimal growth.
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage below 42.65% in an organism's DNA.
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage between 42.65% and 57% in an organism's DNA.
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage between 57% and 66.3% in an organism's DNA.
A genomic feature characterized by a guanine-cytosine content percentage above 66.3% in an organism's DNA.
A cell dimension characterized by a lateral measurement less than 0.5 micrometers across the microbial cell.
A cell dimension characterized by a lateral measurement between 0.5 and 0.65 micrometers across the microbial cell.
A cell dimension characterized by a lateral measurement between 0.65 and 0.9 micrometers across the microbial cell.
A cell dimension characterized by a lateral measurement greater than 0.9 micrometers across the microbial cell.
A cell dimension characterized by a longitudinal measurement less than 1.3 micrometers along the microbial cell's primary axis.
A cell dimension characterized by a longitudinal measurement between 1.3 and 2 micrometers along the microbial cell's primary axis.
A cell dimension characterized by a longitudinal measurement between 2 and 3 micrometers along the microbial cell's primary axis.
A cell dimension characterized by a longitudinal measurement greater than 3 micrometers along the microbial cell's primary axis.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures below 10°C, typical of psychrophilic organisms.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 10°C and 22°C, common in psychrophilic or psychrotolerant organisms.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 22°C and 27°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 27°C and 30°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 30°C and 34°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures between 34°C and 40°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms.
A temperature optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at temperatures above 40°C, typical of thermophilic organisms.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures below 10°C, characteristic of psychrophilic organisms.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 10°C and 22°C, characteristic of psychrophilic or psychrotolerant organisms.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 22°C and 27°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 27°C and 30°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 30°C and 34°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures between 34°C and 40°C, characteristic of mesophilic organisms.
A temperature range allowing microbial growth at temperatures above 40°C, characteristic of thermophilic organisms.
A pH optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 0 and 6, characteristic of acidophilic organisms.
A pH optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 6 and 7, characteristic of neutrophilic or alkali-tolerant organisms.
A pH optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 7 and 8, characteristic of neutrophilic, alkaliphilic, or alkali-tolerant organisms.
A pH optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 8 and 14, characteristic of alkaliphilic or extremely alkaliphilic organisms.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 0 and 4, characteristic of extremely acidophilic organisms.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 4 and 6, characteristic of acidophilic organisms.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 6 and 7, characteristic of neutrophilic organisms.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 7 and 8, characteristic of neutrophilic or alkaliphilic organisms.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 8 and 10, characteristic of alkaliphilic organisms.
A pH range allowing microbial growth at hydrogen ion concentrations between pH 10 and 14, characteristic of extremely alkaliphilic organisms.
A salinity optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations below 1%, characteristic of non-halophilic or halotolerant organisms.
A salinity optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations between 1% and 3%, characteristic of slight halophiles or halotolerant organisms.
A salinity optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations between 3% and 8%, characteristic of moderate halophiles or halotolerant organisms.
A salinity optimum manifested as maximum microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations above 8%, characteristic of extreme halophiles.
A salinity range allowing microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations below 1%, characteristic of non-halophilic organisms.
A salinity range allowing microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations between 1% and 3%, characteristic of slight halophiles.
A salinity range allowing microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations between 3% and 8%, characteristic of moderate halophiles.
A salinity range allowing microbial growth at sodium chloride concentrations above 8%, characteristic of extreme halophiles.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a narrow range less than 1 pH unit.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a range between 1 and 2 pH units.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a range between 2 and 3 pH units.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a range between 3 and 4 pH units.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a range between 4 and 5 pH units.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of pH conditions that support an organism's growth, with a wide range between 5 and 9 pH units.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of sodium chloride concentrations that support an organism's growth, with a narrow range less than 1%.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of sodium chloride concentrations that support an organism's growth, with a range between 1% and 3%.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of sodium chloride concentrations that support an organism's growth, with a range between 3% and 8%.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of sodium chloride concentrations that support an organism's growth, with a wide range greater than 8%.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a narrow range between 1°C and 5°C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a range between 5°C and 10°C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a range between 10°C and 20°C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a range between 20°C and 30°C.
A growth tolerance metric measuring the span of temperatures that support an organism's growth, with a wide range greater than 30°C.
A cell with multiple branches or extensions.
A short rod-shaped cell, intermediate between bacillus and coccus.
A curved, crescent-shaped cell.
A cell with a slight curve or bend.
A cell with a curved spiral shape.
Two spherical cells attached to each other.
A cell with an elongated oval shape.
A long, thin, thread-like cell.
A cell with a spindle-like shape, wider in the middle and tapering at both ends.
A cell with a spiral shape, forming a three-dimensional helix.
A cell with an inconsistent or non-uniform shape.
A cell with an egg-shaped outline.
A cell with an egg-like shape, slightly elongated.
A cell capable of assuming various shapes.
A cell shaped like a circular band or loop.
A straight, elongated cell.
A perfectly round cell.
A cell with a shape that tapers at both ends.
A cell with a tight, coiled shape.
A cell that can assume star-shaped, dumbbell-shaped, or various other forms.
A cell with a main body and a tail-like extension.
A physiological adjustment that enables an organism to survive and reproduce at a specific temperature range.
A set of mechanisms that allows an organism to maintain homeostasis in environments with particular salt concentrations.
A combination of cellular processes that permits survival and growth under specific hydrogen ion concentrations.
A classification of resistant dormant structures produced by bacteria based on their formation and properties.
A set of physiological and molecular mechanisms that enable survival under specific hydrostatic pressure conditions.
The span of hydrostatic pressures within which an organism can maintain viability and cellular functions.
